<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Pursuant to our agreement with Embraer, the 100 ERJ-145XR option aircraft can be converted to some
other types of aircraft within the ERJ-145 Family at our discretion.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>(h) Intangible Assets
&ndash;</i></font></b></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></i></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> Reorganization
Value in Excess of Amounts Allocable to Identifiable Assets represents an amount that arose from Continental&rsquo;s emergence from
bankruptcy reorganization in 1993.&nbsp; Effective January 1, 2002, we adopted and began to account for this asset in accordance
with Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No. 142&ndash;&ldquo;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&rdquo; (&ldquo;SFAS
142&rdquo;).&nbsp; SFAS 142 requires testing of goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives for impairment rather than
amortizing them.</p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We evaluate the carrying value of
this asset each reporting period to determine whether events and circumstances continue to support an indefinite useful life.&nbsp;
We perform an impairment review on an annual basis, or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate that the
asset may be impaired.&nbsp; Our review includes the acquisition, market-multiple and income approaches to valuation.&nbsp; If this
review indicates that our Reorganization Value in Excess of Amounts Allocable to Identifiable Assets will not be recoverable, the
carrying value is reduced to the fair value.&nbsp; We performed this review during 2005, 2004 and 2003 and determined that we did
not have any impairment of our Reorganization Value in Excess of Amounts Allocable to Identifiable Assets.&nbsp; Our annual
impairment test is performed as of June 30 of each year.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Due to Continental&rsquo;s
announcement on December 28, 2005 that it intended to withdraw 69 aircraft from the capacity purchase agreement beginning in
December 2006, we determined a trigger event occurred.&nbsp; In accordance with our policy, we performed an SFAS 142 impairment
analysis as soon as reasonably possible after the trigger event, using the latest data available.&nbsp; No impairment was
identified.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Airport operating rights, the
rights to use certain take-off and landing slots and gates, are amortized on a straight-line basis over the life of the related
airport facility lease, which approximates 20 years, with no residual value.&nbsp; Debt issuance cost, capitalized costs related to
our senior convertible notes, is amortized on a straight-line basis over 20 years, the term of the notes, and with no residual
value.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>(i) Investments in Other
Entities &ndash;</i></font></b></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></i></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Certain investments in
unconsolidated companies that are not variable interest entities are accounted for by the equity method of accounting when we have
significant influence over the operation of the companies as prescribed by Accounting Principles Board Opinion No.
18&ndash;&ldquo;The Equity Method of Accounting for Investments in Common Stock&rdquo; (&ldquo;APB 18&rdquo;).&nbsp; The following
table describes our current non-controlling interests that are accounted for under the equity method of accounting:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="624">
<tr>
<td valign="bottom">
<p align="center"><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Company</font></b></p>
</td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom">
<p align="center"><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Percentage of<br />
 Ownership</font></b></p>
</td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="bottom">
<p align="center"><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Carrying Amount<br />
 of Investment at<br />
 December 31, 2005<br />
 (in millions)<sup>(4)</sup></font></b></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<div align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial"></font>
<hr size="1" width="100%" align="right" />
</div>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<div align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial"></font>
<hr size="1" width="100%" align="right" />
</div>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<div align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial"></font>
<hr size="1" width="100%" align="right" />
</div>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Wing Holdings, LLC<sup>(1)</sup></font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Arial">49%</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">$</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Arial">5.8</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">American Composites, LLC<sup>(2)</sup></font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Arial">49%</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Arial">0.8</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">JetX Aviation Limited<sup>(3)</sup></font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Arial">One share less than 50%</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Arial">0.6</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(1)</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">We purchased our interest in Wing Holdings in June 2005 for $16.0 million in cash.&nbsp; The
carrying amount of our investment exceeded the amount of underlying equity of Wing Holdings by approximately $8.5 million at the
time of our investment.&nbsp; We evaluated the net book value of Wing Holdings&rsquo; fixed assets as of June 30, 2005 and
identified approximately $1.9 million difference between net book value and fair value.&nbsp; The majority of this difference will
be amortized over ten years, the average life of the assets identified.&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005, the balance of the fair
value difference, net of amortization, is approximately $1.4 million.&nbsp; The remaining $6.6 million of our difference in the
underlying investment is considered goodwill and thus, is not amortized.&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(2)</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">In July 2005, we purchased our interest in American Composites and certain land and related
improvements from a party related to American Composites for approximately $5.8 million in cash.&nbsp; We recorded $4.9 million of
the purchase price as building, land and related improvements and the balance was recorded as our non-controlling
investment.</font><font size="2">&nbsp;</font> No difference between the carrying amount of our investment and the underlying
equity of American Composites was identified.&nbsp;</p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(3)</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">In March 2005, we purchased our investment in JetX Aviation for approximately $0.9 million.&nbsp;
The carrying amount of our investment exceeded the amount of underlying equity of JetX Aviation by approximately $0.5 million at
the date of the investment.&nbsp; This difference is considered goodwill and thus, is not amortized.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(4)</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Although no impairment losses on these investments have been recognized, an impairment loss would be
recorded whenever a decline in value of an equity investment below its carrying amount was determined to be other than
temporary.&nbsp; In judging &ldquo;other than temporary,&rdquo; we would consider the length of time and extent to which the fair
value of the investment has been less than the carrying amount of the equity investment, the near-term and longer-term operating
and financial prospects of the equity company and our longer-term intent of retaining the investment in the entity.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>(j) Deferred Credits
&ndash;</i></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our spare part and flight
training credits are primarily derived from our purchase agreement with Embraer.&nbsp; All spare part credits are used to offset
the purchase price of initial spare parts provisioning for our newly delivered aircraft.&nbsp; Similarly, the flight training
credits are used to pay for the initial simulator rent costs for our pilots.&nbsp; These credits are recorded in long-term
liabilities, with an offsetting entry to prepayments and other current assets or current accrued liabilities if we used more
credits than the amount we are entitled to at year-end.&nbsp; The deferred credits are amortized as a reduction to our aircraft
rent expense over the life of the associated aircraft lease.&nbsp; Amortization totaled $0.9 million for each 2005 and 2004.&nbsp;
The prepayments and other current assets or current accrued liabilities are reduced as the credits are used or as the remaining
firm order aircraft are delivered.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>(k) Operating Revenue
&ndash;</i></font></b></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></i></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> We recognized our
operating revenue under the capacity purchase agreement based on negotiated rates for each scheduled block hour Airlines flies for
Continental.&nbsp; The rates were designed to provide Airlines with a target operating margin of 10% before taking into account
variations in some costs and expenses that are generally controllable by Airlines.&nbsp; We also record other revenues earned under
the capacity purchase agreement, such as percentage of completed flights, certain on-time departures and baggage handling.&nbsp;
See &ldquo;&ndash; Note 2&rdquo; for details of the block hour rates and the performance incentive payments.&nbsp; Our operating
revenue is reconciled and settled with Continental on a monthly basis, except for the quarterly reconciliation of Airlines&rsquo;
costs within the margin band as defined in the capacity purchase agreement.</p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Certain amounts billed by us to
Continental under the capacity purchase agreement are subject to our interpretation of the capacity purchase agreement.&nbsp;
Beginning in 2005, we were required to negotiate the block hour rates with Continental annually.&nbsp; If the rates were not
finalized, we would be required to estimate these rates and record revenue based on such estimates until final rates are agreed to
with Continental.&nbsp; In addition, even if Continental concurs with the block hour rates, it may dispute amounts billed and pay
less than the amount invoiced if it interprets the capacity purchase agreement differently than we do.&nbsp; The rates we use to
calculate our operating revenue are based on our interpretation of the capacity purchase agreement.&nbsp; If our interpretation
materially differs from Continental&rsquo;s, our revenue could be materially understated or overstated.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; All fully-reconciled costs
incurred in connection with the capacity purchase agreement are recorded as expense and revenue on a gross basis except for certain
costs such as fuel costs above our fuel and related tax cap and facility rent at Continental&rsquo;s hubs.&nbsp; These costs are
absorbed by Continental under the terms of the capacity purchase agreement and as such we are not the primary obligor for these
costs and accordingly, these costs are not recorded as either revenue or expense by us.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>(l) Wages, Salaries and
Related Expenses &ndash;</i></b></font></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></i></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> As our collective
bargaining agreements become amendable, we accrue for anticipated retroactive pay that we estimate will be due under the new
contract.</p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>(m) Maintenance and Repair
Costs<a name="OLE_LINK10">&ndash;</a></i></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> Maintenance and
repair costs for owned and leased flight equipment, including the overhaul of aircraft components, are charged to operating expense
as incurred, except for those maintenance costs covered by power-by-the-hour agreements, which are expensed based on contractual
terms.&nbsp; In 2005 and 2004, power-by-the-hour arrangements represented approximately 70% of our maintenance, materials and
repairs costs.</p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>(n) Income Taxes
&ndash;</i></font></b></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></i></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> Deferred income
taxes, which are provided under the liability method, are determined based on differences between the financial reporting and
income tax basis of assets and liabilities and are measured using enacted tax rates and laws.&nbsp; A valuation allowance is
provided on deferred tax assets if, based on available evidence, it is more likely than not that future tax benefits will not be
realized.</p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>(o) Earnings per Share
&ndash;</i></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We account for earnings per share
in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No. 128 <font color="black">-</font> &ldquo;Earnings per
Share.&rdquo; Basic earnings per common share (&ldquo;Basic EPS&rdquo;) excludes dilution and is computed by dividing net income
available to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the periods presented.&nbsp;
Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other obligations to issue common stock were
exercised or converted into common stock or resulted in the issuance of common stock that then shared in the earnings of the
company.&nbsp; The following table sets forth the reconciliation of the numerator and denominator of Basic EPS to the numerator and
denominator of Diluted EPS for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004, and 2003 (in thousands, except per share
amounts):</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="bottom">
<p><b><font size="2" face=
"Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></b></p>
</td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td colspan="7" valign="bottom">

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We excluded 287,563 and 123,750
shares of restricted stock from the weighted average shares used in computing Basic EPS for the year ended December 31, 2005 and
2004, respectively, as these shares were not vested as of these dates.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We adopted the Emerging Issues
Task Force Issue No 04.08 &ndash; &ldquo;The Effect of Contingently Convertible Debt on Diluted Earnings per Share&rdquo;
(&ldquo;EITF 04-08&rdquo;) on December 15, 2004.&nbsp; As a result, we included the potential common stock equivalents related to
our senior convertible notes in our computation of Diluted EPS and restated all prior periods in which the convertible notes were
outstanding, as shown in the table above.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The weighted average common
shares outstanding for the Diluted EPS calculation also includes the incremental effect of shares that would be issued upon the
assumed exercise of stock options and vesting of restricted stock.&nbsp; We excluded the following common stock equivalents from
our Diluted EPS calculations, because their inclusion would have been anti-dilutive:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">options to purchase 1.6 million, 1.1 million and 1.0 million shares of our common stock for the
years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp; These options' exercise prices were greater than the average
market price of the common shares for the respective periods; and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">0.2 million and 0.1 million shares of restricted stock for the year ended December 31, 2005 and
2004.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>(p) Stock Plans and Awards
&ndash;</i></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have two stock-based
compensation plans: the ExpressJet Holdings, Inc. 2002 Stock Incentive Plan (the &ldquo;Incentive Plan&rdquo;) and the ExpressJet
Holdings, Inc. 2003 Employee Stock Purchase Plan (the &ldquo;ESPP&rdquo;).&nbsp; We accounted for our stock-based compensation
arrangements using the intrinsic value method in accordance with Accounting Principles Board Opinion No. 25 <font color=
"black">-</font> &ldquo;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees&rdquo; (&ldquo;APB 25&rdquo;) and related interpretations through
December 31, 2005.&nbsp; In December 2004, the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No. 123 (Revised 2004) <font
color="black">-</font> &ldquo;Share-Based Payments&rdquo; (&ldquo;SFAS 123R&rdquo;) which we adopted on January 1, 2006 as our
method of accounting for our stock-based compensation.&nbsp; See a detailed description of SFAS 123R and its impact on our
financial statement below in &ldquo;<font color="black">-</font>(s) Recently Issued Accounting Standards&rdquo;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Incentive Plan permits us to
grant stock options and restricted stock to our outside directors and our employees.&nbsp; Under APB 25, if the exercise price of
our stock options equals the fair market value of the underlying stock on the date of grant, no compensation expense is
recognized.&nbsp; Since our stock options have all been granted with exercise prices at fair market value, no compensation expense
has been recognized under APB 25.&nbsp; We recognize compensation expense related to our restricted stock in accordance with the
provisions of APB 25.&nbsp; The total compensation expense to be incurred for each restricted stock grant equals the product of the
number of shares issued and the closing price of our common stock on the grant date and is recognized over the vesting period of
each grant in accordance with the method specified in FASB Interpretation No. 28<font color="black">-</font>&ldquo;Accounting for
Stock Appreciation Rights and Other Variable Stock Option or Award Plans&rdquo; (&ldquo;FIN 28&rdquo;).&nbsp; Under APB 25, we do
not recognize compensation expense related to the ESPP.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On November 4, 2005, our board of
directors approved accelerating the vesting of 669,750 unvested options with exercise prices of greater than $11.00 per share and
extended the life of 868,500 options that had a five-year term to seven years.&nbsp; This modification did not impact our results
of operations for the year ended December 31, 2005 as these options had no intrinsic value at the modification date.&nbsp; Also,
see detailed discussion of this event below in &ldquo;-Note 11.&rdquo;</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following table illustrates
the effect on net income and earnings per share assuming the compensation cost for our stock option, restricted stock and employee
stock purchase plans were determined using the fair value method, prorated over the vesting periods in accordance with FIN 28, at
the grant dates as required under SFAS 123R for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

</td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom">
<div align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial"></font>
<hr size="4" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="right" />
</div>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom">
<div align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial"></font>
<hr size="4" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="right" />
</div>
</td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom">
<div align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial"></font>

</div>
</td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The increase in stock based
employee compensation expense in 2005 was due to accelerating the vesting and modification of the term of options as described
above.&nbsp; See &ldquo;<font color="black">-</font>Note 11&rdquo; for the assumptions we used to compute the pro forma amounts
above.&nbsp; The pro forma effect on earnings per share is not representative of the pro forma effects in future years.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>(q) Comprehensive Income
&ndash;</i></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We do not have any adjustments to
net income to arrive at comprehensive income.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>(r) Financial Instruments
and Risk Management &ndash;</i></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>Financial Instruments
&ndash;</i> Our financial instruments consist of cash and cash equivalents, short-term investments, accounts receivable, accounts
payable, our long-term secured debt to EDC, note payable to Continental and 4.25% senior convertible notes due 2023.&nbsp; The
carrying amount of cash and cash equivalents, short-term investments, accounts receivable and accounts payable approximate fair
value due to the highly liquid nature of these short-term instruments.&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005 and 2004, the fair value of
our long-term secured debt to EDC was approximately $15.0 million and $15.8 million, respectively.&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005,
the carrying value of the note payable to Continental approximates fair value as we expect to pay off this debt in March
2006.&nbsp; The fair value of our note payable to Continental as of December 31, 2004 was approximately $97.5 million.&nbsp; The
fair values of these instruments were estimated based on the discounted future cash flows using our current incremental rate of
borrowing for a similar liability or market prices.&nbsp; The fair value of our 4.25% senior convertible notes due 2023 was
approximately $112.8 million and $139.1 million based on the quoted market price as of December 31, 2005 and 2004,
respectively.&nbsp; As of December 31, 2004, we also had one share of non-voting Series A Preferred Stock, par value $.01 per share
outstanding.&nbsp; The carrying value of our Series A Preferred Stock at December 31, 2004 approximated fair value.&nbsp; We
redeemed this instrument in April 2005.&nbsp; See &ldquo;-Note 6&rdquo; below.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>Credit Risk Due to Certain
Concentrations &ndash;</i> We provide Continental substantially all of its regional jet capacity at its hub airports as well as
additional non&ndash;hub service.&nbsp; We are economically dependent upon Continental as substantially all of our revenue is
received from Continental.&nbsp; See Item 1A. &ldquo;Risk Factors&rdquo; for detailed discussions. &nbsp; If Continental defaults
on the payment obligations it has to us under our capacity purchase or other agreements, then in addition to any other remedies we
may have, we can offset the amount of the defaulted payments against the amounts we owe to Continental under the note payable to
Continental.&nbsp; In addition, we can reduce any payments we owe to Continental under any agreements in an amount corresponding to
its defaulted payments.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, approximately 70% of
our employees were covered by collective bargaining agreements at December 31, 2005.&nbsp; We amended our contracts with our
pilots, dispatchers and mechanics in 2004.&nbsp; The new contracts will be amendable in December 2008, July 2009 and August 2009,
respectively.&nbsp; Our contract with our flight attendants, which represent approximately 16% of our employees, became amendable
in December 2004.&nbsp; See Item 7.&nbsp; &ldquo;Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations&rdquo; for a discussion on the status of our negotiations with the IAM.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>(s) Recently Issued
Accounting Standards</i> &ndash;</b></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In December 2004, the FASB issued
SFAS 123R, requiring companies to measure the cost of employee services received in exchange for an award of equity instruments
(typically stock options) based on the grant-date fair value of the award.&nbsp; The fair value is to be estimated using an
option-pricing model.&nbsp; The resulting cost will be recognized over the period during which an employee is required to provide
service in exchange for the award, usually the vesting period.&nbsp; Under the original SFAS 123, this accounting treatment was
optional with pro forma disclosures required.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We adopted SFAS 123R on January
1, 2006, as required by SFAS 123R.&nbsp; It is effective for all awards granted after that date and for the unvested portion of
awards granted prior to the adoption date.&nbsp; The expense recognized with respect to unvested awards is based on the grant-date
fair value and vesting schedule of those awards used in calculating the pro forma disclosures required under SFAS 123 and presented
in &ldquo;-(p) Stock Plans and Awards.&rdquo;&nbsp; The impact of adopting SFAS 123R on our statement of operations was similar to
the pro forma impact of SFAS 123 presented in &ldquo;-(p) Stock Plans and Awards.&rdquo;&nbsp; The adoption of SFAS 123R did not
affect our overall financial position or liquidity.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; SFAS 123R also requires the
benefits of tax deductions in excess of recognized compensation cost to be reported as a financing cash flow, rather than as an
operating cash flow as required under current literature. &nbsp; This requirement will reduce net operating cash flows and increase
net financing cash flows in periods after adoption.&nbsp; We cannot estimate the impact of this change in the future (because they
depend on, among other things, when employee exercise stock options).&nbsp; We recognized immaterial excess tax deductions in our
operating cash flows in 2005 and 2004 related to the vesting of our restricted stock. No excess tax deductions in our operating
cash flows were recognized in 2005, 2004 and 2003 related to our options as no options were exercised in these periods.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>(t) Reclassifications
&ndash;</i></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Certain reclassifications have
been made in prior years&rsquo; financial statements to conform to the current year presentation.&nbsp; Additionally, we classified
our auction rate securities as cash equivalents in 2003.&nbsp; In 2004, these securities were reclassified to short-term
investments.&nbsp; The 2003 balance sheet and cash flow statement were reclassified to conform to current presentation.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 2 &ndash; Capacity Purchase Agreement with Continental</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>General.</i></b>&nbsp; We
currently derive substantially all of our revenue from our capacity purchase agreement with Continental.&nbsp; Under this
agreement, Airlines operates flights on behalf of Continental as Continental Express.&nbsp; Continental controls and is responsible
for scheduling, pricing and managing seat inventories and is entitled to all revenue associated with the operation of the
aircraft.&nbsp; We also have various other agreements with Continental that govern our relationship.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Under the capacity purchase
agreement, some marketing-related costs normally associated with operating an airline are borne by Continental.&nbsp; These costs
include:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">reservations and
sales;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>

<tr>

</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">food and beverage service.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On December 28, 2005, Continental
gave us notice of its intention to withdraw 69 aircraft from the capacity purchase agreement beginning in December 2006 and ending
in June 2007.&nbsp; The capacity purchase agreement gives us up to nine months from the notice date to decide if we want to retain
the aircraft.&nbsp; If we choose to retain the aircraft, the capacity purchase agreement contains a provision for the interest rate
implicit in calculating the scheduled lease payments we make to Continental to increase by 200 basis points.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Compensation and
Operational Responsibilities.</i></b><i></i>&nbsp; Under the capacity purchase agreement, Airlines is entitled to payment for each
block hour that Continental schedules it to fly.&nbsp; Payment is based on a formula designed to provide Airlines with a target
operating margin of 10% before taking into account variations in certain costs and expenses that are generally within our
control.&nbsp; In accordance with the capacity purchase agreement, the original cost components used in this formula remained in
place until December 31, 2004, after which new rates are to be established annually with the same methodology.&nbsp; We have
exposure for most labor costs and some maintenance and general administrative expenses, if the actual costs are higher than those
reflected in our block hour rates.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Beginning in the fall of 2004, we
negotiate with Continental to adjust the scheduled block hour rates annually as required under the capacity purchase
agreement.&nbsp; The agreement calls for rates to be set by November 1 of each year.&nbsp; See detailed discussion of 2006 rate
setting below.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>2003-2004.</i></b>&nbsp; A
reconciliation payment was made by Continental to Airlines, or by Airlines to Continental, if the operating margin calculated, as
described below (the "prevailing margin") was not between 8.5% and 11.5% in any fiscal quarter.&nbsp; When the prevailing margin
exceeded 11.5%, Airlines paid Continental an amount sufficient to reduce the margin to 11.5%.&nbsp; If the prevailing margin was
less than 8.5%, Continental would have paid Airlines an amount sufficient to raise the margin to 8.5%; however, from 2003 to 2004,
the quarterly prevailing margins were never below 8.5%.&nbsp; Certain items were excluded from the calculation of the prevailing
margin, including:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">actual labor costs that differed from those reflected in Airlines&rsquo; block hour
rates;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">performance incentive payments, including payments from controllable cancellation performance
(cancellations other than weather or air traffic control cancellations);</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">litigation costs outside the normal course of business; and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">other costs that were not included in Airlines&rsquo; block hour rates (or covered by any
adjustments to them) and were not reasonable and customary in the industry.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; If these excluded costs were
higher than those anticipated in Airlines&rsquo; block hour rates, its operating margin could have been lower than 8.5% when taking
these costs into account, even after any reconciliation payment was made.&nbsp; Conversely, if these costs were lower than those
anticipated in Airlines&rsquo; block hour rates, its operating margin could have been higher than 11.5% when taking these costs
into account, even after any reconciliation payment was made.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During 2004, Airlines&rsquo;
quarterly reconciliation payments to Continental totaled $61.0 million.&nbsp; The table below describes how variations between our
actual costs and our estimated costs, as determined in the block hour rates, were treated under the capacity purchase agreement
through 2004:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">

payment was to be made by Continental or Airlines to the other so that this prevailing margin would be 8.5% or 11.5%, as

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;</font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<tr>
<td valign="top">

</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Under the fuel purchase agreement with Continental, in 2004 and 2003, fuel and fuel tax expense were
reconciled to the lower of the actual costs or the agreed-upon caps of 66.0 cents per gallon and 5.2 cents per gallon,
respectively, based on our fuel purchase agreement with Continental.&nbsp; If the fuel agreement with Continental were not in
place, Airlines&rsquo; fuel cost, including related taxes, would have been $1.23 and $0.93 per gallon for the years ending December
31, 2004 and 2003, respectively.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(2)</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Depreciation was reconciled for assets and capital projects accounted for in the capacity purchase
agreement or those approved by Continental outside of the capacity purchase agreement.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(3)</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Pilot soft time reconciliation ended March 31, 2003.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(4)</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">In addition to the unreconciled costs listed above, the prevailing margins used to calculate
Airlines&rsquo; quarterly reconciliation payments did not take into account any performance incentive payments, including payments
from controllable cancellation performance (cancellations other than weather or air traffic control cancellations), litigation
costs outside the normal course of business and other costs that were not included in Airlines&rsquo; block hour rates (or covered
by adjustments to them) and were not reasonable or customary in the industry.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In 2004, the fully reconciled
costs, costs within the margin band and unreconciled costs under our capacity purchase agreement represented approximately 63.9%,
12.0% and 24.1% of total operating costs, respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, to the extent that
our rate of controllable cancellations (such as those due to maintenance or crew shortages) was lower than our historical
benchmarks, we were entitled to incentive payments; conversely, we would have had to pay Continental if our controllable
cancellations were above historical benchmarks.&nbsp; Because these incentive benchmarks were based on historical five-year rolling
averages of monthly controllable cancellations, lower controllable cancellations that resulted in higher incentive payments in the
near term reduced our opportunity to earn incentive payments in the future.&nbsp; Also, because we used monthly rolling averages,
our opportunity to earn these payments in any particular fiscal quarter was affected by monthly variations in historical
controllable cancellation rates.&nbsp; We were also entitled to receive a small per-passenger fee and incentive payments for
certain on-time departure and baggage handling performance.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>2005 Rate Negotiation and
Amendment</i>.</b>&nbsp; As part of the 2005 rate negotiation, we agreed to cap Airlines&rsquo; prevailing margin at 10.0%.&nbsp;
Airlines also included previously unreconciled costs within the margin band, although it is not reimbursed if these costs are
higher and cause its prevailing margin to fall below the 8.5% margin floor.&nbsp; In addition, Airlines is still entitled to
receive incentive payments from Continental if its rate of controllable cancellations is lower than its historical benchmark, but
is not required to pay Continental a penalty for controllable cancellations unless the rate rises above 0.5%.&nbsp; Airlines
continued to receive a small per-passenger fee and incentive payments for certain on-time departure and baggage handling
performance.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During 2005, Airlines&rsquo;
quarterly reconciliation payments to Continental totaled $23.4 million.&nbsp; The table below describes how variations between
Airlines&rsquo; actual costs and estimated costs, as determined in the block hour rates, have been treated under the capacity
purchase agreement since January 1, 2005:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Fully reconciled costs: reconciliation payment, including 10% margin, to the full extent actual
costs differ from estimated costs.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial"><br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Fuel and into-plane expenses<sup>(1)</sup><br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Aircraft rent<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Terminal facility rent<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;On-time bonuses and 401(k) company match under<br />
 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;current plans<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Taxes (other than income taxes)<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Passenger liability insurance<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Hull insurance<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;War risk insurance<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Landing fees<br />
 </font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial"><br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Ground handling services<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Administrative services provided by Continental<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Third-party security and screening expenses<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Substantially all regional jet engine expenses under<br />
 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;current long-term third-party contracts<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization<sup>(2)</sup><br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Glycol, de-icing, snow removal<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;International navigational fees<br />
 </font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial"><br />
 Costs within the margin band: if actual expenses in this category are sufficiently different from estimates used in the block hour
rates so that the prevailing margin is less than 8.5% or greater than 10.0%, then a reconciliation payment will be made by either
Continental or Airlines to the other so that this prevailing margin will be 8.5% or 10.0%, as applicable.&nbsp; If the prevailing
margin were less than 8.5% due to the impact of certain costs, as described below, or if the prevailing margin were above 10.0% due
to other items<sup>(3)</sup>, no reconciliation payments would be made from either Continental or Airlines.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial"><br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Maintenance, materials and repairs not included<br />
 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;above<br />
 &nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;Passenger services</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial"><br />
 &bull;&nbsp;Other rental expenses<br />
 &bull;&nbsp;Other operating expenses</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(1)&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Under the fuel purchase agreement with Continental, fuel and fuel tax expense are reconciled to the
lower of the actual costs or the agreed-upon caps of 66.0 cents per gallon and 5.2 cents per gallon, respectively, based on
Airlines&rsquo; fuel purchase agreement with Continental.&nbsp; If the fuel purchase agreement with Continental were not in place,
the fuel cost, including related taxes, would have been $1.80 per gallon for the year ended December 31, 2005.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(2)&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Depreciation is reconciled for assets and capital projects accounted for in the capacity purchase
agreement or those approved by Continental outside of the capacity purchase agreement.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(3)&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">The prevailing margin used to calculate the reconciliation payment does not take into account
performance incentive payments, including payments from controllable cancellation performance, litigation costs above a historical
benchmark and other costs that are not included in the block hour rates (or covered by adjustments to them) or are not reasonable
and customary in the industry.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In 2005, the fully reconciled
costs and costs within the margin band under the capacity purchase agreement represented approximately 64% and 36% of total
operating costs, respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Certain costs that were
unreconciled under the capacity purchase agreement prior to 2005 now require Airlines to make a reconciliation payment to
Continental if the differences cause the prevailing margin to be greater than 10.0%.&nbsp; However, if the differences cause the
prevailing margin to be less than 8.5%, they remain unreconciled.&nbsp; These costs are:</font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">wages and salaries;
and&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">benefits not included in the table above.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>2006 Rate
Setting.</i></b>&nbsp; Because we have not agreed on the 2006 rates, Continental has agreed to continue paying Airlines at the
December 2005 rates until an agreement is reached.&nbsp; Any agreement to revise the current rate structure will be retroactive to
January 1, 2006.&nbsp; We cannot currently estimate what our 2006 rates will ultimately be.&nbsp; If we cannot agree on the 2006
rates, the capacity purchase agreement allows either party to submit the matter to arbitration.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Capacity and Fleet
Matters.</i></b>&nbsp; Subject to the aircraft withdrawal beginning in December 2006, the capacity purchase agreement currently
applies to all of Airlines&rsquo; 266 aircraft, as well as the aircraft subject to firm orders through December 2006, at which time
Continental will withdraw 69 aircraft from the capacity purchase agreement.&nbsp; Under the capacity purchase agreement,
Continental is required to purchase or lease from Embraer or its designee all of our current firm order aircraft under the
agreement, as well as participate in the financing, and to lease or sublease these aircraft to us.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The capacity purchase agreement
also allows us to be Continental&rsquo;s exclusive regional jet service provider at Newark&rsquo;s Liberty International,
Houston&rsquo;s Bush Intercontinental and Cleveland&rsquo;s Hopkins International airports through December 31, 2006.&nbsp;
However, Continental has the right to reduce the number of our regional jets covered by the agreement at any time upon
12&nbsp;months&rsquo; notice.&nbsp; As noted above, on December 28, 2005, Continental gave us notice of its intention to withdraw
69 aircraft from the capacity purchase agreement beginning in December 2006 and ending in June 2007.&nbsp; Under the terms of the
agreement, Continental cannot withdraw additional aircraft from the agreement until December 28, 2009 unless the agreement is
terminated.&nbsp; If the agreement were terminated, withdrawal would be limited to 15 aircraft per month.&nbsp; With respect to the
69 aircraft released from the capacity purchase agreement, we have the option to:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="624">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">fly the released aircraft for other parties or under our own code, subject to our ability to obtain
facilities, such as gates and slots, and subject to our exclusive arrangement with Continental at its hub
airports;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">sublease the aircraft to other parties; or</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">decline to fly these aircraft and cancel the related subleases with Continental.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; If we choose to retain the
aircraft released from the capacity purchase agreement, the capacity purchase agreement has a provision for the interest rate
implicit in calculating the scheduled lease payments we make to Continental to increase by 200 basis points.&nbsp; See Item 1.
&ldquo;Business&ndash;Capacity Purchase and Other Agreements with Continental Airlines &ndash; Aircraft Financing.&nbsp; &rdquo;If
we elect not to retain these aircraft, the related leases or subleases between us and Continental will be canceled, and Continental
will take possession of the aircraft. In that event, Continental will be responsible for all direct reasonable costs we incur in
removing those aircraft from our fleet.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have options for 100 ERJ-145XR
aircraft that may be exercised for other types of aircraft within the ERJ-145 Family.&nbsp; During 2005, Continental declined the
right to exercise any of these options.&nbsp; We retain the right to exercise them and fly these aircraft for other airlines or
under our own code, subject to some restrictions; however, we will have to finance our acquisition of these aircraft
independently.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; So long as scheduled flights
under the capacity purchase agreement with Continental represent either at least 50% of all our scheduled flights or at least 200
of our aircraft are covered by the capacity purchase agreement, we are required to allocate our crews, maintenance personnel,
facilities and other resources on a priority basis to scheduled flights under the capacity purchase agreement above all of our
other flights and aircraft.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Term of
Agreement</i>.</b>&nbsp; The capacity purchase agreement is scheduled to expire on December&nbsp;31, 2010.&nbsp; Continental has
the option to extend the term of the agreement with 24&nbsp;months&rsquo; notice for up to four additional five-year terms through
December&nbsp;31, 2030.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Continental may terminate the
agreement at any time upon 12&nbsp;months&rsquo; notice, or at any time without notice for cause, which is defined as:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="624">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">our bankruptcy;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">suspension or revocation of our authority to operate as a scheduled airline;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">cessation of our operations as a scheduled airline, other than as a result of a union-authorized
labor strike or any temporary cessation not to exceed 14&nbsp;days;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">a union-authorized labor strike that continues for 90&nbsp;days; or</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">our intentional or willful material breach that substantially deprives Continental of the benefits
of the agreement, which is not cured within 90&nbsp;days of notice of the breach.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Continental may also terminate
the agreement at any time upon our material breach that does not constitute cause and continues for 90&nbsp;days after we receive
notice of the breach.&nbsp; If we materially breach the agreement (including for cause) and, for breaches other than cause, fail to
cure the breach within 60&nbsp;days after we receive notice of the breach, we will have to pay Continental an amount equal to the
expected margin contained in the block hour rates for scheduled flights from the 60th day (or immediately, without receipt of any
notice, if the breach is for cause) until the breach is cured.&nbsp; In addition, Continental may terminate the agreement
immediately without notice or giving us an opportunity to cure if it makes a reasonable and good faith determination, using
recognized standards of safety, that there is a material safety concern with our operation of any flight under the capacity
purchase agreement.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; If Continental materially
breaches the agreement and fails to cure the breach within 60&nbsp;days after we notify it of the breach, we will be entitled to
obtain our payments directly from Airline Clearing House, Inc. from the 60th day for the duration of the default.&nbsp; In
addition, Continental and we are each entitled to seek damages and equitable remedies in arbitration.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Continental&rsquo;s
Outlook.</i></b>&nbsp; We are directly affected by Continental&rsquo;s financial and operational stability because we depend on its
ability to make payments to us under our capacity purchase and other agreements.&nbsp; Continental has reported significant losses
since September 11, 2001, excluding special items.&nbsp; For the years ended December 31, 2005 and 2004, Continental reported net
losses of $68 million and $409 million, respectively.&nbsp; Excluding special items, Continental&rsquo;s losses would have been
more significant.&nbsp;</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Continental and the union
representing its flight attendants recently ratified their labor agreement to allow Continental to meet its $0.5 billion
cost-savings goal previously announced; absent additional adverse factors due to external influences, such as additional terrorist
attacks or unreasonable increase in fuel prices, we are not aware of any other factors that would lead us to believe that
Continental will not be able to maintain adequate liquidity through December 31, 2006, as previously disclosed in its quarterly
filings.&nbsp; However, a combination of some or all of several events, most of which are outside of Continental&rsquo;s direct
control, may result in its inability to maintain adequate liquidity through December 31, 2006.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As discussed above, Continental
has reduced the level of its commitment for our aircraft under the capacity purchase agreement, which could materially reduce our
revenue and earnings.&nbsp; Furthermore, Continental leases from third parties a substantial portion of the aircraft and airport
facilities that it subleases to us.&nbsp; If Continental declared bankruptcy or otherwise defaulted under these leases, we would
have no rights to these aircraft or facilities; our access to our aircraft and airport facilities would depend on negotiations
between the lessors and us.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 3 &ndash; Security Fee</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On April 16, 2003, President Bush
signed into law the Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriation Act 2003 (&ldquo;Wartime Act&rdquo;), which was include as part of
a larger bill to fund the war in Iraq.&nbsp; Highlights of the Wartime Act affecting us are as follows:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">$2.3 billion for reimbursement of airline security fees that were paid or collected by airlines as
of the date of enactment, which means reimbursement for fees paid from February 1, 2002 through April 16, 2003, and from June 1 to
September 30, 2003; and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">$100 million was authorized to reimburse carriers for installing fortified flight deck
doors.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In May 2003, we received $3.0
million to reimburse security fees under the Wartime Act. However, since the reimbursement represented fully reconciled costs under
the capacity purchase agreement, we distributed 100% of the funds received to Continental.&nbsp; For detailed discussion of fully
reconciled costs, please see &ldquo;- Note 2.&rdquo;&nbsp; The net impact of this reimbursement was immaterial to our results of
operations.&nbsp; In September 2003, we also received $0.6 million for reimbursement of costs related to installation of the
fortified flight deck doors pursuant to the Wartime Act.&nbsp; The amount received was used to reduce the capitalized cost of our
property and equipment.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On January 3, 2006, Airlines and
42 other carriers received demand notices from the TSA related to the alleged underreported, uncollected ASIF.&nbsp; Airlines was
invoiced by the TSA for an additional $2.1 million for 2005, due on or before February 2, 2006.&nbsp; We recorded this additional
liability as of December 31, 2005, of which $0.8 million was recorded as additional security expense pursuant to a previously
agreed allocation methodology with Continental.&nbsp; On January 16, 2006, Continental and we jointly submitted a letter to the TSA
seeking a joint administrative review of the ASIF assessments and a stay of any related payments.&nbsp; At this time, we cannot
predict the outcome of this review.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 5 &ndash; Leases</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We lease or sublease all 266 of
our aircraft under operating leases with lease terms ranging from 16 to 16.5 years from Continental.&nbsp; Our sublease agreements
with Continental have substantially the same terms as the lease agreements between Continental and the third-party lessors, and
expire between 2013 and 2022.&nbsp; Rental payments for each aircraft are fixed upon lease execution with no escalation
clauses.&nbsp; We also lease or sublease, under various operating leases, ground equipment and substantially all of our ground
facilities, including facilities at public airports from Continental or the municipalities or agencies owning and controlling such
airports.&nbsp; Though the duration and terms of these leases vary greatly, we expect, in most cases, leases to be renewed or
replaced by new leases as required in the normal course of business.&nbsp; Our leases do not include residual value
guarantees.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; At December 31, 2005, the
scheduled future minimum lease payments under capital leases due to third-party lessors and the scheduled future minimum lease
payments under operating leases that have initial or remaining non-cancelable lease terms in excess of one year are as follows (in
millions):</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our total rental expense for all
non-aircraft operating leases was approximately $39.3 million, $33.4 million and $51.5 million for the years ended December 31,
2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Total aircraft and non-aircraft
rent expense was approximately $348.3 million, $314.8 million and $300.6 million for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and
2003, which included $323.3 million, $292.6 million and $280.7 million of payments under leases with Continental under the capacity
purchase agreement.&nbsp; In addition, of the total rental expense, $290.4 million, $262.7 million and $249.4 million are related
to subleases with Continental for 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp; As a result of 2003 amendment to our Master Facility and
Ground Handling Agreement with Continental, we no longer pay Continental rent related to our hub stations.&nbsp; See Item 1.
&ldquo;Business &ndash; Capacity Purchase and other Agreements with Continental Airlines &ndash; Airport Facilities, Slots and
Route Authorities&rdquo; for more detailed description of this amendment.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; If we defaulted on our payment
obligations under our aircraft and facility leases or subleases with Continental, Continental would be entitled to reduce future
payments to us under the capacity purchase agreement by the amount of the defaulted payment.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The scheduled minimum aircraft
operating lease payments in the above table include the estimated reduction for the withdrawal of 69 aircraft beginning in December
2006.&nbsp; The scheduled minimum non-aircraft operating lease payments in the above table include payments for seven new engine
leases. Prior to December 2005, under our power-by-the-hour agreement with Rolls Royce, we were obligated to acquire up to three
spare engines to support our existing aircraft and the remaining eight aircraft on firm order.&nbsp; In December 2005, we
negotiated the sale of eight engines to Rolls Royce and, in exchange, entered into seven new engine leases with a Rolls Royce
subsidiary. The engines leased have greater interchangeability than the engines sold. As a result, we have satisfied our engine
obligations and are no longer obligated to purchase the three engines.&nbsp; These leases are classified as operating leases; hence
they are not reflected as assets and liabilities on our balance sheet.&nbsp; These leases do not have residual value guarantees and
annual escalation of rental payments is based on customer price index.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In July 2005, we purchased
certain building, land and related improvements (from a party related to American Composites) for an aggregate price of
approximately $4.9 million.&nbsp; $4.2 million was recorded as building and related improvements and the balance was allocated to
land.&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005, we have recorded approximately $0.1 million in accumulated depreciation for this
building.&nbsp; At the same time, we lease the building, land and related improvements to American Composites for use in its
operation.&nbsp; We account for the lease as an operating lease.&nbsp; The scheduled minimum future lease payments from American
Composite are to be as follows (in millions):</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>
