<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 6 &ndash; Long-term Debt</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005,
long&ndash;term debt, including current maturities, totaled $15.3 million, which consisted of $15.3 million of secured debt owed to
EDC.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; EDC loaned us $10.7 million in
May 2003 and $6.6 million in September 2003.&nbsp; The loan is secured by certain of our flight simulators, flight data software
and other equipment related to the simulators.&nbsp; We used all of the proceeds from the loans to reduce the principal under our
note payable to Continental.&nbsp; The amount due to EDC accrues interest at the six-month LIBOR plus 1.75% per annum.&nbsp; The
term of each advance to us is 96 months.&nbsp; The loan agreement has customary representations, warranties and covenants.&nbsp;
Additionally, Continental is the guarantor of this loan, and a default under the guarantee would cause an acceleration of the
loan.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Prior to the completion of our
initial public offering, Airlines issued the sole authorized and outstanding share of its non-voting Series A Preferred Stock, par
value $.01&nbsp;per share, to our subsidiary XJT Holdings, Inc. as partial consideration for its assets and liabilities.&nbsp; The
series A Preferred Stock was entitled to receive, on a cumulative basis, dividends at a rate of 14% per annum on a liquidation
preference of $5.0 million, callable beginning in April 2005 and mandatorily redeemable in April 2012.&nbsp; Upon issuance, XJT
Holdings, Inc. sold the Preferred Stock to an independent third party in exchange for a $5.0 million promissory note, with no
rights of offset, due in April 2012.&nbsp; The note bore interest equal to the three-month LIBOR plus 0.6% per annum, payable
quarterly which commenced on August 1, 2002.&nbsp; On July 1, 2003, we adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No.150
&ndash;&ldquo;Accounting for Certain Financial Instruments with Characteristics of both Liabilities and Equity.&rdquo;&nbsp; Upon
adoption, we reclassified our Series A Preferred Stock to long-term debt.&nbsp; We also began to recognize dividends declared
related to our Series A Preferred Stock as interest expense.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On April 1, 2005, Airlines called
the Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock for redemption.&nbsp; The redemption price, including accrued but unpaid dividends, was
approximately $5.0 million.&nbsp; The share was redeemed on April 16, 2005, and the corresponding dividends ceased.&nbsp; In
addition, we received $5.0 million, including accrued but unpaid interest income, from the holder of the stock to retire a $5.0
million promissory note held by us.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Maturities of these long-term
debts are summarized below in &ldquo;&ndash; Note 8.&rdquo;</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 7 &ndash; Note Payable to Continental</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Under the promissory note dated
March 31, 2001, net amounts due Continental were converted into a long-term note payable of $552.3 million, which bore interest at
a fixed rate of 4.9% through June 30, 2001.&nbsp; Effective July 1, 2001, the rate for subsequent quarters was set at the
three-month LIBOR plus 1.25% per annum.&nbsp; The note is our unsecured general obligation and is subordinated in right of payment
to all of our future senior indebtedness and is junior to any of our secured obligations and the secured obligations of our wholly
owned subsidiaries to the extent of the collateral pledged.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In 2004, we made a discretionary
prepayment of $27.0 million in addition to our scheduled quarterly principal and interest payments, net of prepayments made in
prior periods, to the extent required.&nbsp; The quarterly payment on our note payable to Continental for principal and interest is
$27.9 million, to be paid through the earlier of March 31, 2007 or until the principal balance and any accrued interest are paid in
full.&nbsp; We currently expect to pay off this obligation on March 31, 2006.&nbsp; Total payments made during 2005 and 2004
(including the discretionary prepayments) were $84.7 million and $98.8 million, respectively, of which $81.3 million and $94.4
million, respectively, related to principal.&nbsp; Based on the three-month LIBOR on December 31, 2005 plus 1.25% per annum and our
current principal balance of $17.5 million, maturities of our note payable to Continental as of December 31, 2005 are detailed on
the table included in &ldquo;&ndash; Note 8&rdquo; below.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The weighted average interest
rate for the year ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 was 4.4%, 2.6% and 2.5% per annum, respectively.&nbsp; The statements of
operations include total interest charges from Continental of $3.5 million, $4.3 million and $6.7 million for the years ended
December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 8 &ndash; 4.25% Senior Convertible Notes due 2023</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During 2003, we completed the
private placement of $137.2 million senior convertible notes due 2023, which were resold by the initial purchasers to qualified
institutional buyers pursuant to Rule 144A of the Securities Act of 1933.&nbsp; Cash interest is payable on the notes at a rate of
4.25% per year on the principal amount at maturity, payable semiannually in arrears on February 1 and August 1 of each year,
beginning February 1, 2004.&nbsp; The aggregate amount of the principal will be due on August 1, 2023.&nbsp; The notes and the
notes guarantee are senior unsecured obligations and rank equally with our existing and future senior unsecured indebtedness.&nbsp;
The notes and the notes guarantee are junior to any of our secured obligations and the secured obligations of our wholly owned
subsidiaries to the extent of the collateral pledged.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The notes are convertible into
shares of our common stock at a conversion rate of 54.9451 shares per $1,000 in principal amount at maturity of the notes.&nbsp;
This conversion rate is subject to adjustment in certain circumstances.&nbsp; Holders of the notes may convert all or a portion of
their notes into shares of our common stock under the following circumstances: (i) at any time during or after any fiscal quarter
commencing after September 30, 2003 if the closing sale price of our common stock for at least 20 trading days in a period of 30
consecutive trading days ending on the last trading day of the fiscal quarter prior to such quarter is greater than 120% of the
conversion price per share of common stock on such last day; (ii) subject to certain exceptions, during the five business day
period after any five consecutive trading day period in which the trading price per $1,000 principal amount of the notes for each
of the five trading days was less than 98% of the product of the closing sales price of our common stock and the number of shares
issuable upon conversion of $1,000 principal amount of the notes; (iii) if the notes have been called for redemption; or (iv) upon
the occurrence of specified corporate transactions.&nbsp; We have reserved sufficient shares of our common stock to be issued upon
conversion of these notes.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We can redeem the notes, in whole
or in part, beginning on August 4, 2008, at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid cash
interest, if any.&nbsp; The holders of the notes may require us to repurchase the notes on August 1, 2008, August 1, 2013 and
August 1, 2018 (&ldquo;Redemption Dates&rdquo;) at a purchase price equal to 100% of their principal amount, plus accrued and
unpaid interest, if any.&nbsp; We can choose to pay the repurchase price for any such notes in cash, in shares of common stock or
any combination thereof should we be required to redeem the notes at any of the Redemption Dates.&nbsp; We have a shelf
registration statement on file with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the resale of the notes and the underlying
common stock for the security holders name therein.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Proceeds from the offering, net
of initial purchasers&rsquo; fees, were used to repurchase 9,835,125 shares of our common stock from Continental at $13.60125 per
share pursuant to a stock repurchase agreement with Continental.&nbsp; As a result of this repurchase, Continental&rsquo;s
beneficial ownership of our common stock dropped below 50%.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Repayment of the convertible
notes is jointly and severally guaranteed on an unconditional basis by Airlines.&nbsp; Except as otherwise specified in the
indenture pursuant to which the notes were issued, there are no restrictions on Airlines&rsquo; ability to transfer funds to us in
the form of cash dividends, loans or advances.&nbsp; General provisions of applicable state law, however, may limit the ability of
any subsidiary to pay dividends or make distributions to us in certain circumstances.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Separate financial statements of
Airlines are not included herein because the aggregate assets, liabilities, earnings, and equity of that subsidiary remain
substantially equivalent to our assets, liabilities, earnings and equity on a consolidated basis.&nbsp; Airlines is jointly and
severally liable for the repayment of the notes.&nbsp; We do not believe that separate financial statements and other disclosures
concerning Airlines would be material to investors.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The amount of all scheduled debt
maturities, as described in Notes 6, 7 and 8 above, due over the next five years and thereafter is as follows (in
millions):</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Other than the debt obligations
described above, we do not have any other source of long-term borrowings or available lines of credit.&nbsp; There is no covenant
under any of our current long-term debt agreements that restrict our ability to undertake additional debt or equity
financing.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

and the related amounts used for income tax purposes.&nbsp; Significant components of our deferred tax liabilities and assets as of
December 31, 2005 and 2004 are as follows (in millions):</font></p>

</td>

<td valign="bottom">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Net deferred tax assets (liabilities)</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">$</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(48.6</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="bottom">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">)</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">$</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(46.6</font></p>
</td>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">)</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom">
<div align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial"></font>
<hr size="4" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="right" />
</div>
</td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
<td valign="bottom">
<div align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial"></font>
<hr size="4" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="right" />
</div>
</td>
<td valign="bottom"></td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; At December 31, 2004, we had
federal net operating loss carryforwards of approximately $17.4 million, which expire in 2019.&nbsp; In September 2005, Continental
entered into a final settlement agreement with the IRS that included periods when we were included in its consolidated federal
income tax return.&nbsp; Our taxable income was not adjusted, but the amount of net operating losses allocated to us was reduced by
approximately $16.4 million.&nbsp; In accordance with our tax agreement with Continental, we recorded a receivable from Continental
for approximately $5.7 million for the reduction of our federal net operating loss carryforwards.&nbsp; In addition, we adjusted
our tax accounts to reflect a federal net operating loss carryforward at December 31, 2004 of approximately $1.0 million, which was
utilized in 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In conjunction with our initial
public offering in April 2002, the tax basis of our tangible and intangible assets was adjusted to fair value.&nbsp; This
adjustment to tax basis should result in additional tax deductions being available to us through 2017.&nbsp; In accordance with our
tax agreement with Continental, to the extent we generate taxable income sufficient to realize the additional tax deductions, we
are required to pay Continental a percentage of the amount of tax savings actually realized, excluding the effect of any loss
carrybacks.&nbsp; We are required to pay Continental 100% of the first third of the anticipated tax benefit, 90% of the second
third and 80% of the last third.&nbsp; However, if the tax benefits are not realized by the end of 2018, we will be obligated to
pay Continental 100% of any benefit realized after that date.&nbsp; Since these payments are solely dependent on our ability to
generate sufficient taxable income to realize these deferred tax assets, they are recorded as an obligation to Continental within
the deferred tax asset accounts, and the portion we may retain in the future is offset by a valuation allowance.&nbsp; At the time
of the initial public offering, the valuation allowance and the obligation to Continental offset the step-up in basis of assets in
our long-term deferred tax asset account.&nbsp; We made approximately $25.3 million and $57.0 million of net payments to
Continental under the tax agreement during 2005 and 2004, respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The tax agreement requires
Continental to reimburse us for any net increase in our cash tax payments resulting from any decreased availability of net
operating loss carryovers related to the basis increase at the time our payment occurs.&nbsp; The resulting receivable and/or
payable is recorded within the deferred tax asset account since its performance is dependent on our ability to generate taxable
income.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; No valuation allowance was
established on our net operating loss carryforwards or on our receivable from Continental for reimbursing carryforward losses
utilized resulting from the basis increase because we believe our stand-alone taxable income will be sufficient to utilize
substantially all of these assets within the next several years.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We believe that our initial
public offering created a change in ownership limitation on the utilization of our federal tax attribute carryforwards, primarily
net operating losses.&nbsp; Section 382 of the Internal Revenue Code limits our utilization of these attributes to offset up to
approximately $43.3 million of post-change taxable income per year.&nbsp; This limitation did not have any impact on our financial
condition during the years ending 2005 and 2004.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our tax agreement increases our
dependence on Continental&rsquo;s financial condition.&nbsp; If it is determined that any of the tax benefits related to the basis
increase should not have been available at the time of utilization and, as a result, we are required to pay additional taxes,
interest and penalties, then we could be adversely affected if Continental were unable to indemnify us under the
agreement.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 10 <a name="OLE_LINK16">&ndash;</a> Preferred, Common and Treasury Stock</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Preferred
Stock.</i></b>&nbsp; We have 10 million shares of authorized preferred stock, par value $.01 per share.&nbsp; One share of
preferred stock was issued and outstanding at December 31, 2004.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; After Continental&rsquo;s
ownership of common shares fell below 10% on April 7, 2005, we redeemed the sole share of our Special Voting Preferred Stock held
by Continental. The redemption terminated Continental&rsquo;s right to elect a director to our board of directors. Pursuant to our
capacity purchase agreement, Continental had the right to nominate a director to our board, but relinquished this right, effective
October 2005. Continental currently owns less than 10% of our common stock and has indicated that it intends to dispose of some or
all of its remaining shares, subject to market conditions.&nbsp; We do not believe that Continental&rsquo;s sale of its ownership
interest will have an adverse impact on our results of operation or financial position.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our board is divided into three
classes, and our directors are elected by stockholders for three-year terms.&nbsp; Two of the classes are comprised of two
directors and the third is comprised of three.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Common Stock.</i></b>&nbsp;
We currently have one class of common stock, par value $.01 per share, with 54.7 million shares issued.&nbsp; Each share of common
stock is entitled to one vote.&nbsp; Common stockholders participate ratably in any dividends or distributions on the common
stock.&nbsp;</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Treasury
Stock.</i></b>&nbsp; In July 2005, our board of directors authorized the expenditure of up to $30 million to repurchase shares of
our common stock.&nbsp; Purchases have been made from time to time in the open market; the timing of any share repurchases under
the program depends on a variety of factors, including market conditions, and may be suspended or discontinued at any time.&nbsp;
Common stock acquired through the program will be available for general corporate purposes.&nbsp; In 2005, we purchased 590,800
shares of our common stock at an average cost per share of $9.55.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, under the Incentive
Plan, our board of directors can approve the issuance of restricted stock to various employees and non-employee directors.&nbsp;
Forfeitures of awarded shares resulted in common stock held in treasury from which subsequent restricted stock awards can be issued
and stock option exercises can be satisfied.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 11 &ndash; Stock Based Compensation Plans</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; At December 31, 2005, we had a
stock incentive plan and an employee stock purchase plan.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Stock Incentive Plans.&nbsp;
Prior to the completion of our initial public offering, Continental, as our then sole stockholder, and our board of directors
approved the Incentive Plan, which was subsequently ratified by our public stockholders in 2003.&nbsp; The Incentive Plan provides
that we may grant awards in the form of stock options or restricted stock to our non-employee directors, our employees or employees
of our subsidiaries.&nbsp; The aggregate number of shares of our common stock that may be issued under the Incentive Plan may not
exceed 3.2 million shares, subject to adjustments as provided in the Incentive Plan.&nbsp; We have reserved 3.2 million shares of
our common stock for issuance under this plan.&nbsp; Options granted under the Incentive Plan have been awarded with exercise
prices equaling the fair market value of the stock on the date of grant, vest over a four-year period for employees or a six-month
period for non-employee directors and expire seven years after the date of grant in the case of employees and ten years after the
date of grant in the case of directors.&nbsp; During 2005, 2004, and 2003, we issued 489,500, 155,500 and 389,000 options,
respectively, to purchase our common stock under the Incentive Plan, with a grant date fair value of approximately $2.4 million,
$1.4 million and $3.2 million, respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On November 4, 2005, our board of
directors approved accelerating the vesting of 669,750 unvested options currently held by employees, including executive officers,
with exercise prices greater than $11.00 per share and extended the term of 868,500 employee options that had a five-year term to
seven years.&nbsp; These options were and remain out of the money, and the acceleration and extension were effective
immediately.&nbsp; No options held by non-employee directors were subject to acceleration or extension.&nbsp; The acceleration of
vesting reduces compensation expense upon the adoption of SFAS 123R.&nbsp; The reduction in compensation expense in the future,
based on our implementation date of January 1, 2006, was approximately $3.1 million.&nbsp; We reported this future compensation
expense in our 2005 pro forma footnote disclosures, as permitted under the transition guidance provided by the
FASB.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In 2005 and 2004, our board of
directors approved the issuance of 214,750 and 135,750 shares of restricted stock, respectively, net of forfeitures, to various
employees and non-employee directors pursuant to the Incentive Plan, with fair value totaling $2.1 million and $1.7 million,
respectively.&nbsp; The restricted shares granted to our employees to date vest ratably over three or four-year periods.&nbsp;
Restricted shares granted to our non-employee directors vest over six months. Total expense recognized related to restricted stock
for the year ended December 31, 2005 and 2004 was $1.6 million and $0.7 million, respectively.&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005 and
2004, we had 287,563 and 123,750 shares of restricted stock outstanding.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Continental has stock option and
incentive plans under which our employees were granted awards of Continental common stock in the form of stock options or
restricted stock (the &ldquo;Continental Plans&rdquo;).&nbsp; Our employees&rsquo; eligibility to participate in the Continental
Plans ceased in August 2003, when Continental&rsquo;s beneficial ownership of our common stock dropped below 50%.&nbsp; All options
outstanding were either exercised or cancelled in 2003.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The table below summarizes stock
option transactions pursuant to the Incentive Plan and Continental Plans (share data in thousands):</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following tables summarize
the range of exercise prices and the weighted average remaining contractual life of our options outstanding and the range of
exercise prices for our options exercisable at December 31, 2005 (share data in thousands):</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td colspan="8" valign="top">
<p align="center"><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Options Outstanding</font></b></p>
</td>
<td>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</td>
</tr>

</div>
</td>
<td>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">

</div>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Employee Stock Purchase
Plans.&nbsp; On May 7, 2003, our stockholders approved the ESPP, which authorized the sale of up to one million shares of our
common stock.&nbsp; We have reserved one million shares of our common stock for issuance under the ESPP.&nbsp; Under the plan, all
of our employees are eligible to purchase shares of our common stock at 85% of the lower of the fair market value on the first or
last day of the semi-annual purchase period.&nbsp; Our first purchase period began on July 1, 2003.&nbsp; Employees may sell shares
obtained under the ESPP six months after the end of the plan period in which the shares were purchased.&nbsp; During 2005 and 2004,
69,347 and 72,970 shares, respectively, of our common stock were issued to our employees at prices ranging from $7.23 to $10.37 in
2005 and prices ranging from $10.32 to $12.75 in 2004.&nbsp; In January 2006, we issued 39,985 shares of our common stock to our
employees at $6.88 per share.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Pro Forma SFAS 123 Results.&nbsp;
Pro forma information regarding net income and earnings per share, as detailed in &ldquo;&ndash;Note 1&ndash;Summary of Significant
Accounting Policies&ndash;(p) Stock Plans and Awards,&rdquo; has been determined as if we had accounted for our stock options and
stock purchase plan under the fair value method of SFAS 123.&nbsp; The fair value of Holdings&rsquo; options granted during 2005,
2004 and 2003 was estimated at the date of grant using the Black-Scholes options pricing model with the following weighted-average
assumptions for 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively: risk-free interest rate of 3.9%, 3.5% and 3.3%, dividend yield of 0%, expected
life of the option of 4.8, 7.4 and 6.6 years and expected volatility of Holdings&rsquo; stock of 55.0%, 68.7% and 69.3%.&nbsp;
Volatility used for options granted in 2005 was based on the actual volatility of our stock.&nbsp; 2004 and 2003 volatility was
calculated as an average of the volatility of our and other comparable regional airlines&rsquo; stock as our historical data is
only available from April 23, 2002.&nbsp; We changed the method used to estimate volatility in 2005 because we believe this is more
reflective of our actual volatility than using an industry average.&nbsp; The weighted-average grant date fair value of the stock
options granted in 2005, 2004 and 2003 was $5.02, $8.96 and $8.03 per option, respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The fair value of the purchase
rights under the ESPP was also estimated using the Black-Scholes model with the following assumptions for 2005, 2004 and 2003,
respectively: risk-free interest rate of 3.8%, 2.0% and 1.0%, dividend yield of 0%, expected volatility of Holdings&rsquo; stock of
60.8%, 57.3% and 53.7% and an expected life of six months.&nbsp; The weighted-average fair value of each purchase right granted in
2005, 2004 and 2003 was $2.51, $3.53 and $4.20, respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Black-Scholes option
valuation model was developed for use in estimating the fair value of traded options, which have no vesting restrictions and are
fully transferable.&nbsp; In addition, option valuation models require the input of highly subjective assumptions including the
expected stock price volatility.&nbsp; As a result, we believe there are limitations in the Black-Scholes option valuation model
when calculating the fair value of our options and purchase rights.&nbsp; However, due to the limited historical data related to
our stock compensation, we believe the Black-Scholes option valuation model currently provides the best estimate.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<b><font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font></b>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 12 &ndash; Employee Benefit Plans</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Effective December 31, 2002, the
ExpressJet Airlines, Inc. 401(k) Savings Plan (&ldquo;401(k) Plan&rdquo;) was adopted.&nbsp; Substantially all our domestic
employees are covered by this plan.&nbsp; Under the plan, we offered the following benefits:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">a retirement match up to 5.0% of pay per person (which vests over five years); and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">a service-based match (which vested immediately), depending on years of service and the terms of the
collective bargaining agreements, as applicable.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Effective October 1, 2004 for
Airlines&rsquo; mechanics, who are represented by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and January 1, 2005 for all other
employees, the 401(k) Plan was amended.&nbsp; Under the amended plan, we offer the following benefits:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">a service-based retirement match from 4.0% up to 6.0% of pay per person (which vests over five
years) depending on years of service; and&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">a service-based retirement contribution (with 5-year cliff vesting) depending on years of service
and the terms of the collective bargaining agreements, as applicable.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; For the years ended December 31,
2005, 2004 and 2003, our total expense for the defined contribution plan was $18.2 million, $14.5 million and $10.8 million,
respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The ExpressJet Airlines, Inc.
Profit Sharing Plan (the &ldquo;Profit Sharing Plan&rdquo;) was adopted effective January 1, 2002 and amended on February 17,
2005.&nbsp; Under this plan, if Airlines achieves a 10% operating margin, the Profit Sharing Plan will pay out 5% of eligible base
pay received during the year to our eligible employees, which excludes employees whose collective bargaining agreements provide
otherwise and employees who participate in our management bonus program or any other bonus program designated by the Human
Resources Committee of our Board.&nbsp; Profit sharing expense for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 was $11.0
million, $10.0 million, and $8.3 million, respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We also provide medical bridge
coverage for employees between the age of 60 to 65, with at least 10 years of service who have retired from the company.&nbsp; As
of December 31, 2005 and 2004, our benefit obligation was $2.6 million and $1.8 million, respectively. Total expense recognized
related to this obligation for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 was $0.6 million, $0.7 million and $1.3
million.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 13 &ndash; Commitments and Contingencies</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Capacity Purchase
Agreement.</i></b>&nbsp; So long as Continental is our largest customer, if we enter into a capacity purchase or economically
similar agreement with another major airline (defined as any airline with annual revenues greater than $500 million, prior to
adjustment for inflation since 2000) to provide regional airline service for more than 10 aircraft on terms and conditions that
are, in the aggregate, less favorable to us than those in the capacity purchase agreement, the capacity purchase agreement has a
provision that may allow Continental to amend its agreement with us to conform to the terms and conditions of our new
agreement.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, there are provisions
in the capacity purchase agreement that require us to use commercially reasonable efforts to transfer, subject to applicable laws,
to Continental or its designee any of our airport take-off or landing slots, route authorities or other regulatory authorizations
used for Airlines&rsquo; scheduled flights under the agreement.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Continental is generally
responsible for all capital and start-up costs for airport terminal facilities at its hub airports and at any other facilities
where it elects to provide baggage handling services to us.&nbsp; If Continental elects to provide baggage handling services at any
facility where we previously provided baggage handling services, Continental will reimburse us for most of the capital and start-up
costs we incurred at that facility.&nbsp; We are generally responsible for any capital and start-up costs associated with any
airport terminal facilities at other airports where we fly and any non-terminal facilities not regularly used by Continental.&nbsp;
If we exit a market at the direction of Continental (and we do not re-enter that market under our own code or that of an airline
other than Continental within six months), Continental will reimburse us for certain losses incurred in connection with the closure
of the related facility.&nbsp; If the capacity purchase agreement is terminated, we may be required to vacate the terminal
facilities (or all facilities if the termination results from our material breach of the agreement) that are subleased to us by
Continental, and to use commercially reasonable efforts to assign to Continental or designee any lease in our name for these
facilities.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Purchase
Commitments.</i></b>&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005, we had firm commitments to acquire 8 regional jets from Embraer through
2006.&nbsp; The estimated aggregate cost of these firm commitments is approximately $0.2 billion.&nbsp; We will not have any
obligation to take any of the aircraft under firm commitments if they are not financed by a third party and leased or subleased to
either Continental or us.&nbsp; We also have options to purchase an additional 100 Embraer regional jets.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Prior to December 2005, under our
power-by-the-hour agreement with Rolls Royce, we were obligated to acquire up to three spare engines to support our existing
aircraft and the remaining eight aircraft on firm order.&nbsp; In December 2005, we negotiated the sale of eight engines to Rolls
Royce and, in exchange, entered into seven new engine leases with an affiliate of Rolls Royce. The engines leased have greater
interchangeability than the engines sold. As a result, we have satisfied our engine obligations and are no longer obligated to
purchase the three engines.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We also have other contractual
obligations of approximately $1.3 billion under our power-by-the-hour contracts with various service providers.&nbsp; The
power&ndash;by-the-hour contracts dictate the method by which we pay a vendor based on our actual level of operations in exchange
for vendor coverage on specific parts and equipment on our aircraft when those parts and equipment are in need of repair or
replacement.&nbsp; As a result of these agreements, our overall future maintenance costs will not increase; however, our short-term
future costs will be higher, as we forego our warranty of these components and systems in return for future cost savings, insurance
and more predictable maintenance expense.&nbsp; These agreements are expected to provide a better match of expenses with the usage
of the aircraft.&nbsp; Each contract varies in term and payment procedure.&nbsp; The estimated amount of our future commitment is
based on assumptions related to future level of operations and forecasted payment rates.&nbsp; Our level of operations is
determined by Continental, which has exclusive scheduling authority over our fleet under the capacity purchase agreement.&nbsp; The
level of operation inherent in the estimate is based on Continental&rsquo;s most recent operating plan for us, which can be altered
at Continental&rsquo;s sole discretion.&nbsp; Forecasted payment rates are based on actual rates as of December 31, 2005 and
increased annually according to the particular inflation index detailed in each individual contract.&nbsp; Contractual rate
increases at actual time of occurrence may be different than the forecasted rates</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; See a summary of all our
contractual obligations in Item 7. &ldquo;Management&rsquo;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations &ndash; Liquidity and Capital Commitments &ndash; Contractual Obligations and Commercial Commitments.&rdquo;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>General Guarantees and
Indemnifications.</i></b>&nbsp; Pursuant to the capacity purchase agreement, we indemnify Continental for certain of our actions
and it indemnifies us for some of its actions.&nbsp; During 2004, we incurred $4.0 million in other operating expenses relating to
a claim by Continental for costs incurred during the post-retirement storage of certain turboprop aircraft
engines.&nbsp;</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Additionally, we are party to
many contracts, in which it is common for us to agree to indemnify third parties for tort liabilities that arise out of or relate
to the subject matter of the contract.&nbsp; In some cases, this indemnity extends to related liabilities that arising from the
negligence of the indemnified parties, but typically excludes liabilities caused by gross negligence or willful misconduct.&nbsp;
We cannot estimate the potential amount of future payments under these indemnities until events arise that would trigger a
liability under the indemnities.&nbsp; However, we expect to be covered by insurance for a material portion of these liabilities,
subject to deductibles, policy terms and condition.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<b><i>Employees.</i></b><i></i>&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005, approximately 70% of our employees are covered by collective
bargaining agreements, which include pilots, mechanics, dispatchers and flight attendants.&nbsp; Our contracts with our pilots,
dispatchers and mechanics will be amendable in December 2008, July 2009 and August 2009, respectively.&nbsp; Our contract with our
flight attendants, which represents approximately 16% of our employees, became amendable in December 2004.&nbsp; We are currently
engaged in labor negotiations with our flight attendants.&nbsp; At this time we cannot predict the outcome of these
negotiations.&nbsp; Our other employees are not covered by collective bargaining agreements.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Legal
Proceedings.</i></b>&nbsp; We are a defendant in various lawsuits and proceedings arising in the ordinary course of our
business.&nbsp; While the outcome of these lawsuits and proceedings cannot be predicted with certainty and could have a material
adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations or cash flows, we do not believe that the ultimate disposition of
these proceedings will have a material adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 14 &ndash; Related Party Transactions</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following is a summary of
significant related party transactions that occurred during the three years ended December 31, 2005, other than those discussed
elsewhere in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Continental controls the
scheduling, ticket prices and seat inventories with respect to Airlines&rsquo; operations.&nbsp; In connection with this activity,
Continental performs all sales and ticketing functions for Airlines on Continental ticket stock and receives cash directly from the
sale of Airlines&rsquo; tickets.&nbsp; Continental purchases or provides payment of certain items on our behalf, including fuel,
certain payroll expenditures (including related benefits) and insurance, and charges us amounts as stipulated in the capacity
purchase agreement.&nbsp; In general, transfers or sales of assets between us and Continental are recorded at net book
value.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Continental provides various
services to us and charges us amounts at rates in accordance with the capacity purchase and other agreements.&nbsp; The services
provided to us by Continental are as follows.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Certain customer services such as ground handling.&nbsp; Charges related to these services were
approximately $75.3 million, $106.5 million and $90.1 million for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">Centralized services and infrastructure costs, such as technology, transaction processing, treasury
and risk management.&nbsp; Charges related to these services were approximately $8.7 million, $13.8 million and $14.4 million for
the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004, and 2003.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During 2004, we amended our
administrative support and information services provisioning agreement with Continental, which primarily extended the agreement for
the term of the capacity purchase agreement.&nbsp; We also amended the capacity purchase agreement to incorporate the amendment to
our power-by-the-hour agreement with Rolls Royce that was signed in September 2004.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Effective November 1, 2003, we
amended our master facility and ground handling agreement with Continental to clarify how Continental allocates rent expenses to us
at the airport locations where Airlines operates.&nbsp; Under this amendment, all terminal facility rents at the hub airports are
now borne by Continental and Airlines pays for incremental rent at other Continental&ndash;managed locations unless Continental
does not operate any aircraft there.&nbsp; In these situations, Airlines is responsible for the rent expense.&nbsp; At locations
Airlines manages, rent is allocated between Continental and Airlines based on the number of respective passengers.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In December 2005, we recorded a
current receivable from Continental in the amount of $1.7 million related to the reimbursement of the life-limited parts used on
seven of the eight engines sold to Rolls Royce.&nbsp; This receivable is included in &ldquo;Amounts due from Continental Airlines,
Inc., net&rdquo; on the face of the balance sheet.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During 2003, we finalized our
2002 income tax returns reflecting the tax impact of our spin-off from Continental.&nbsp; Upon reconciling the tax impact of the
spin-off in our deferred tax accounts, a deferred tax asset of approximately $6.7 million remained.&nbsp; At the end of 2003, this
asset was included in our deferred tax accounts.&nbsp; In 2004, based on Continental&rsquo;s agreement with our reconciliation and
the conclusion that this asset was related to our spin-off from Continental, the item was reclassified as a receivable from
Continental.&nbsp; In December 2004, we reached an agreement with Continental under which it agreed to pay half of this
balance.&nbsp; As a result, in the fourth quarter we recorded a $3.4 million charge in other operating expenses.&nbsp; Continental
paid us the remaining balance as full and final satisfaction of this matter in January 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We also have related-party
transactions between us (including our subsidiaries) and our equity investees or Continental.&nbsp; The following quantifies such
activities:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">In July 2005, we purchased a 74,000 square foot maintenance facility shop in Miami, Florida for $4.9
million.&nbsp; We lease this property to American Composites, in which we own a 49% interest, under an operating lease.&nbsp; Rent
revenue from American Composites totaled approximately $0.2 million in 2005.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">During 2005, Wing Holdings and American Composites, in which Holdings owns a non-controlling
interest, provided approximately $0.2 million and $0.1 million worth of services to Airlines, respectively.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">

for Wing Holdings in the amount of $0.1 million.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">&bull;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">During 2005, InTech, a wholly owned subsidiary of Holdings since November 2005, reported sales to
Continental totaling $0.8 million.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005 and 2004,
we had approximately $0.7 million of receivables from our employees (which does not include any of our officers).&nbsp; These
receivables are related to uniforms, flight benefit charges and membership fees that are paid back to us through payroll
deductions.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Arial">Note 15 &ndash; Subsequent Event</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In February 2005, our board of
directors authorized the inclusion of our 4.25% convertible notes due 2023 in our previously announced $30 million securities
repurchase program, which includes our common stock.&nbsp; We expect any purchases of the notes or the stock to be made from time
to time in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions. The timing of any repurchases under the program will depend on
a variety of factors, including market conditions, and may be suspended or discontinued at any time. Common stock acquired through
the repurchase program will be available for general corporate purposes, and convertible notes repurchased under the program will
be cancelled.</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Arial"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="672">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(1)&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">The sum of the individual quarterly earnings per share does not agree with year-to-date net income
per share as each quarterly computation is based on the weighted average number of shares outstanding during that
period.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(2)&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">We adopted EITF 04-08 in 2004.&nbsp; As a result, we restated our Diluted EPS to include the
potential common stock equivalents related to our senior convertible notes in our computation of Diluted EPS for all periods in
which the convertible notes were outstanding (since August 2003).</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Arial">(3)&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Arial">See detailed reconciliation of the numerator and denominator of Basic EPS to the numerator and
denominator of Diluted EPS at - Note 1 - Summary of Significant Accounting Policies - (o) Earnings per Share."</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
